results.title: The Mountain does it for me
results.creator_credit: Oak Creek Films, Len Aitken and Bill Snider
results.brief_description: Describes a ski program devised for youngsters with cerabral palsy. Looks at both the skiing and the special training and educational approach in the Children’s Hospital, Denver, Colorado. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Oak Creek Films, Len Aitken and Bill Snider

results.title: The Mountain
results.creator_credit: State Film Centre of Victoria, Tapley Timms, Leo Fowler, Robert Forster and H. Rodney Power
results.brief_description: George O’Brien and boy, Ian Timms, set out to climb Sugarloaf Peak near Buxton, north-east Victoria. Using his knowledge of bushcraft, the boy leads the climb with the man as a back-up to correct his mistakes. The man leads on the way down - the most difficult for finding the correct way to not get lost. George O’Brien is convenor of the Search & Rescue section of the Federation of Victorian Walking Clubs.

results.title: The Mountain
results.creator_credit: Faces West Productions, Stephen E Bettcher, Claudio Romero Serafini and Martin McNamara
results.brief_description: This modern fable is an allegory for a multitude of problem solving situations, ranging from substance abuse to social issues. It tells of a small village situated at the foot of “the Mountain” immersed in controversy through a rash of problems related to the mountain. The citizens frantically attempt a series of simplistic and ineffectual programs but these hasty measures only aggravate the problems and further divide the community. Finally reason prevails and the villagers calmly address their mountain related problems by seeking positive solutions.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Faces West Productions, Stephen E Bettcher, Claudio Romero Serafini and Martin McNamara

results.title: The Motorman
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Bernard Devlin and Gil LaRoche
results.brief_description: A day in the life of a streetcar motorman shows him transporting hundreds of people to their places of business or to and from stores. We are shown the public as individuals, with little idiosyncracies and personal approaches to boarding a streetcar-amusing, or not, depending on the point of view-which are received with equanimity by the long-suffering driver. Photographed by Lorne C. Batchelor.

results.title: The Mothers of Acari
results.brief_description: This film tells how Acari, a town in the interior of Brazil, came to possess a modern Maternity and Child Welfare Clinic. Initially, the clinic was established in a small house, but when UNICEF commenced the distribution of powdered milk, a bigger and better clinic became necessary. For the mothers of Acari, it was a new experience to receive constant care before, during and after the birth of their babies.

results.title: The Mother and the whore = La Maman et la putan
results.creator_credit: Elite Films, Cine Qua Non, Les Films du Losange, Simar Films, V.M. Productions, Pierre Cottrell and Jean Eustache
results.brief_description: Jean-Pierre Leaud is a young intellectual who has relationships with two very different women, the faithful Marie and the promiscuous Veronika. “The Mother and the Whore” is an exploration of contemporary sexual relationships which concentrates on the bohemian subcultures of the disillusioned left. Dialogue, argument and dialect are what this film focuses upon, allowing for a candid and radical re-examination of the meaning of commitment and desire, as well as examining the often cataclysmic effects of feminism on gender roles and expectations. Winner of the Special Jury Prize at the 1973 Cannes Film Festival, “The Mother and the Whore” remains one of the most important and most admired of “Nouvelle Vague” cinema. The irony being, of course, is that in its detached over-view of the games between men and women, and in it’s ruthless mocking of the insularity of the French intelligentsia, the film initiates a clear break with the passionate and romantic idealism of the sixties new wave.
results.title_for_label: The Mother and the whore = La Maman et la putan

results.title: The Mother (2003)
results.creator_credit: BBC Film Unit, Kevin Loader and Roger Michell
results.brief_description: Having spent her whole life in the ‘accepted’ role of wife and mother, elderly May appears distant and unaffectionate. Not very loved by either of her two adult children, May and husband Toots travel to London for a visit with the family. On the sudden death of her husband, May has an affair with a man half her age, who is also her daughter’s boyfriend. The film explores contemporary life in London and the way families live with the dynamic of demands of work and relationships. It also proves age is no reason for loss of sexual desire but what about moral ethics?

results.title: The Moth of Moonbi
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Productions and Charles Chauvel
results.brief_description: Charles Chauvel’s first feature tells the story of a country girl, Dell Ferris (the Moth of Moonbi), drawn to the bright lights of the big city where her inheritance is soon frittered away with high society revelling. A wiser Dell returns to Moonbi Station where she is beset by the cattle rustler Jack Bronson, but finally finds peace and happiness with the faithful head stockman, Tom. Cast includes Darla Townend, Colleen Richards, Charles O’Mara, Marsden T. Hassell, Doris Ashwin, Arthur Tauchert.

results.title: The most wonderful egg in the world
results.brief_description: Animated adaptation of Helme Heine’s vivid watercolours complemented by a subtle medieval score played on guitar and oboe. Three vain hens are each determined to win the title of princess by laying the most wonderful egg.

results.title: The Most important question in the world
results.creator_credit: ACMI, ACMI Digital Storytelling and Paul Young
results.brief_description: When Paul Young went to university, he knew he didn’t want to be a teacher. However, over time, he has seen the value of the profession and learnt that it’s not about the content, it’s about the life lessons.
